Generally I agree that testing private methods is a bad idea. However 
there may be valid exceptions where functional decomposition is 
appropriate within one class, and therefore private, but is complex 
enough to be tested.

My interpretation of JUnit's design is that it is agnostic towards 
testing private methods because it is a function of the VM whether 
they are accessible at all. Since modern VMs allow it, we can do it 
where appropriate. My current approach is to actively generate a 
proxy class that exposes private methods where necessary which I 
discuss in a different thread.

Regards,

David
